summary: This is a formal letter from defense attorney Laura A. Menninger to the U.S. Attorney's Office requesting access to physical evidence, 'highly confidential' materials, and scene visits related to the Ghislaine Maxwell case. The letter specifically requests that Maxwell be present for evidence review and proposes dates for inspection.

persons.name: Laura A. Menninger
persons.context: Attorney representing Ghislaine Maxwell, writing to formally request access to evidence and materials in the case.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The accused in the criminal case referenced (United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell), for whom the defense attorney is requesting evidence access and presence during review.

persons.name: Ms. Comey
persons.context: Addressee of the letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office, presumably involved in the prosecution of the case.

events.title: Proposed Evidence Review Session
events.description: Defense proposes to review physical evidence and 'Highly Confidential' materials in the Ghislaine Maxwell case, requesting Maxwell's presence.

events.title: Proposed Evidence Review Session (continued)
events.description: Potential continuation of the evidence review session due to anticipated volume of materials.

locations: United States Attorney's Office Southern District of New York, 1 St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
Haddon Morgan and Foreman, P.C., 150 East 10th Avenue, Denver, Colorado 80203
Epstein properties (referenced generally, locations not specified)
keyFacts: The defense formally requested access to all physical evidence seized in the Ghislaine Maxwell case, including items designated as 'Highly Confidential'.
The defense specifically requested that Ghislaine Maxwell be present and able to participate in the evidence review process.
The defense indicated an intent to visit and inspect physical scenes of alleged illegal conduct, including Epstein properties referenced in the Superseding Indictment.
The letter references a 'Protective Order' governing the handling of 'Highly Confidential' materials in the case.
The defense anticipated the evidence review would require more than one eight-hour session due to the volume of materials seized.
